Dear Ms. Hill:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
8/26/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(5) An agency shall involve the child’s parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster parents
to understand the plan for the child and the parents’ and
the foster parent’s role in assisting the agency in carrying
out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to and review
the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or
parents and foster parents. The agency must inform the
parent or parents and foster parent that the information
in the parent-agency treatment plan and any other
information about the child and the child’s family is
confidential.
One of three files reviewed documented late signatures on two PATP's.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (a) Within 30 calendar days from removal
from the home.
2

One of three files reviewed contained a late report. The report was due 1/18/2025
and was completed 2/4/2025.
Repeat Violation:
08/22/2024 Renewal CAP approved 09/25/2024
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• The agency was informed DCWL is no longer auditing any DHHS Policy. DCWL
Consultants will only be auditing rules described in the "Licensing Rules For
Child Placing Agencies" rule book.
• The agency was also informed that a social work contact documenting the foster
care worker reviewed the PATP with the foster parent and other relevant parties
and provided them with a copy of the treatment plan would meet the rule when
obtaining signatures was not possible
V. CONSULTATION
• Consultation was not requested or provided at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency submitted an approved corrective action plan on 9/25/24 in response to
those violations established in the 8/22/2024 renewal inspection. The rule and
policy violations are as follows. FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans, FOM 722-06B
Family Team Meetings, FOM 801-03 Medical Passports, and Rule 400.12418,
Development of services plans. The agency CAP was successful in preventing
repeat violations except for Rule 400.12418. The current Interim Inspection
established a repeat violation of the rule.
3

Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrators assessment was reviewed. The assessment documents
review of the agency 2024 audit CAP and agency efforts to comply with the CAP.
The assessment documents that there were no identified barriers which would
impact rule and policy compliance. The assessment reports further that there
were three unplanned discharges involving one youth. The youth has severe
behavioral problems and is now placed with a relative. It was noted that there can
be a lack of foster homes that can handle difficult youth.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted an annual budget and a certified public accountant annual
audit. No concerns were identified.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported enjoying working for the agency They reported that agency
supervisors and the administration is supportive of them and they have a unified,
committed team.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is located in a modern, well maintained facility in Traverse city. There
is sufficient office space for staff, a conference room and rooms for visitation.
CHRI documents were observed to be secured.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The CPA Analyst generated two safety alerts during her visits to the homes. They are
as follows:
Safety Alert # 1. A safety alert was generated on 7/3/2025 as there was not a smoke
alarm between the master bedroom and the rest of the home. The smoke alarm was
reinstalled while the Analyst was at the home.
Resolution: Resolution was achieved on 7/3/2025.
Safety Alert # 2. A safety alert was generated on7/10/2025 as the home did not have a
smoke alarm between basement bedrooms and the rest of the home. There also was
no smoke alarm between the main floor sleeping bedrooms and the rest of the home.
Resolution: Resolution was achieved on 7/23/25 as alarms were installed and photos
provided of the installed alarms.
4

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
